posts.name: Dylan
posts.cooked:
Hi, my team is having an issue right now where our robot is browning out while driving around. We tried testing the robot for several hours trying to find the root of the issue, but had no luck. The only somewhat working solution was setting a current limit in software for the drive motors at 40 amps, but even then we still had an occasional brownout. It’s odd we are getting these brownouts because our robot from last year used about the same drive base setup with about the same code.

Things we tried checking:

Different batteries (and confirmed they were charged with a battery beak)

Replaced the main breaker

Checked the resistance between the battery connection and the PDH

Running only 2 drive motors (Still had brownouts with only 2 NEOs!)

I also noticed in the rev hardware client our Spark Maxes had Gate Driver sticky faults, but they did not persist after power cycling the robot.

Robot Specs:

4x NEOs (Drive Base)

1x NEO (Arm, turned off for testing)

1x Compressor (Turned off for testing)

1x PDH

1x Pigeon IMU

1x RIO 2.0

1x Radio with Rev POE injector

Logs from the evening: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1PTo3xOXasKPNWxjKOFRJqQXA2E59Dots/view?usp=share_link

Current code:

Main Robot Code 2023. Contribute to panthertech292/2023_r development by creating an account on GitHub.

If anyone has got any ideas or solutions, they are very much appreciated!

posts.name: bardd
posts.cooked: Did you make sure there aren’t any mechanical issues? Maybe the chain is rubbing arainat something and causing friction, maybe some carpet fibers got stuck on the shaft… Try putting the robot up on blocks and turning the wheels by hand. Does it feel smooth? Do you have any hard points? It should be fairly easy to turn the wheels by hand without the robot’s weight on them. Also, did you try running it with the robot on blocks and see if you still have issues? By the way, what is your gear ratio?

posts.name: Dylan
posts.cooked:
Might as well and try this, but even if it was a mechanical issue I’m not sure if that would be causing the brown outs.

Forgot the gear ratio. I’ll have to ask mechanical tomorrow and do more testing then.

posts.name: SamM
posts.cooked: It could be high resistance somewhere in your electrical system between the battery and the rio. Double check the bolted connections on the battery terminals and the main breaker. Also check the battery internal resistance (Rint on the battery beak). It should be below 0.020. Below 0.017 would be best. The higher the internal resistance and resistance in your power connections, the more the battery voltage will drop under load.

posts.name: Jesse
posts.cooked:
A little more info. new drive base with new gearbox and new belts and wheels. drive components runs super smooth with no binding.

made sure the wires entering the PDP were stripped enough.

checked the resistance between the Anderson connector and the inlet to PDP with volt meter and it’s ~0.7ohm.  this is similar to another robot we checked.

we tried unplugging everything except two neo’s and still had problems. I feel like we have a high resistance somewhere but can’t for the life of me figure out where.  it’s not that complicated.

could this be a sparkmax or motor grounding issue? (winding or switch fault) checked with motor current set to factory of 80a and had to lower it to 40a to keep it from acting up.  still seeing voltage drop to 8v.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
If you pull all the breakers except the arm does it still happen?

When you run the drivetrain have you tried it on blocks?  This will identify a turning scrub issue.

Can you post pictures?

posts.name: Jesse
posts.cooked: haven’t tried just the arm. we have tried just moving forward and reverse only with no turning with the same problem. I can post up some video later today.

posts.name: SamM
posts.cooked:
0.7 ohms is unrealistically high. You can find the voltage drop across your wires with oh Ohm’s Law V=IR,  so for 0.7 ohms, and lets say 6A of current, you would get a 4.2V drop just between the anderson and the PDP. So ignoring battery and all other resistance a 6A current, would drop the voltage the rio sees from 12V to 7.8V.

With a 0.07 ohm resistance, you could have 80A with a 5.6V drop, plus a bit more drop from the battery which would be in line with what you’re seeing brown-out wise.

To find the resistance, I assume you’re measuring the resistance between the positive contact on the anderson and the positive terminal on the PDP, and adding that to the resistance between the ground contact and terminal to get your 0.7 ohms total resistance?

posts.name: Jesse
posts.cooked: yes, 0.7ohm does seem high and I expected the value to be wrong using the cheap multimeter we had instead of micro ohm meter, but I wanted to get a sense if we were in crazy town or just a little off by comparing it to another robot using the same meter.  I was really hoping something would stand out as the problem.  I do think the problem is between the pdp and the battery but there just isn’t that much stuff between the two.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
In your github link you don’t have any sort of motor controller configuration or manual tuning that could help smooth out the torque demanded by your motors.

You could look into WPILib’s SlewRateLimiter , or if the Neos have something built in where you can control the open loop control voltage ramp rate it may help.

The number you use calculated in units/sec.  So, if you’re talking about a range value from (-1, 1), which you are because you’re using ArcadeDrive from WPILib, then a rate limiter instantiated with 3.0 will be from 0->Full in 1/3 of a second. For some reason it took me far longer than it should have to realize that was the implementation when we first started using them last year.

The nice thing about a SlewRateLimiter over the built-in ramp rates of the motor controllers we use is that you can limit things differently in the forward and reverse directions whereas the motor controllers we have apply the ramp rate in both directions.

posts.name: Basel Alghanem
posts.cooked: Could be insufficient gear ratio but I highly suspect it’s a system resistance issue. Anderson connectors to the battery, connections at the main breaker, at the PDP. I agree that 0.7 ohms is extremely high. You’re aiming for low 20s in milliohms for total system resistance.

posts.name: Brennan Macaig
posts.cooked:
A few things…

For the battery → PDP pathway; please check that every connection is tight. For example, the post on the battery which is held to the wire via a bolt/nut, this should not be able to rotate. If this connection can rotate, that means that it is not tight enough. Double check all of these connections - no connection should be able to “wiggle” at all (the main breaker, PDP/PDH, battery are all held down this way).

What is the internal resistance of your batteries, and your robot weight? You said you have a battery beak, IR should be the bottom number on a battery beak. Unfortunately, the am14u toughbox default gear ratio changed this year to be pretty aggressive, which means for a robot of 120lb with a battery IR of .017, you will be browning out. Your battery IR should be as close to .013 as possible. We typically recycle batteries when they reach .020

A slew rate limiter should not be necessary for a kitbot drive train to prevent brownouts. While this certainly could help, that’s not a solution to the problem, it’s a solution to the symptom of the problem.

To recap, check that all your connections from Battery → PDP are tight and do not wiggle. If the connector can turn/wiggle, that means that you are increasing your resistance in the wire.

If that’s not the problem, we’ll need to know the IR of your batteries, and the robot weight.

posts.name: Jesse
posts.cooked: I can check on the battery IR later tonight. our bot at the moment weighs right at 100lbs without battery or bumpers we are geared up to 5.95:1 with 6" 8wd wheels.

posts.name: JOEL340
posts.cooked:
Using JVN’s design calculator from back in the day you are drawing way to many amps to each motor with only a 5.95:1 Gear ratio.

GearRatio_1 859×441 66.1 KB

GearRatio_1 859×441 66.1 KB

GearRatio_1 859×441 66.1 KB

Maybe try changing the gear ratio to lower the amps that each motor is drawing.

Another thing to check is to make sure the motors are going in the same direction. Im assuming they are but its another thing that can be crossed off the list.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked:
Building on this. image 454×1193 199 KB

image 454×1193 199 KB

image 454×1193 199 KB

Using the frc calculator it is showcasing a stage 2 brownout. Meaning any pushing force and you’re battery is going quick. It’ll show some more metrics based on what Joel has. I may have some dimensions off since I’m not sure your drivebase. Let me know and I can update it.

posts.name: Brennan Macaig
posts.cooked: Yeah unfortunately you’ll need to change your gear ratio here. There’s no way that any battery that’s FRC legal can support this gear ratio with this weight. The stock kitbot ratio (~8.75:1) will probably be good enough.

posts.name: Dylan
posts.cooked:
Here is our battery from last night. (It was at 100% charge when we first started using it) 20230309_163445 1299×1585 244 KB

20230309_163445 1299×1585 244 KB

20230309_163445 1299×1585 244 KB

If the gear ratio is the issue, that is kinda weird. Our bot from last year used the same ratio I believe and weighed 125 pounds. It never really had any issues with browning out. We have some extra weight on the robot (16 pounds) that we can remove. Will test without the extra weight.
did your bot las year use 4" diameter wheels or 6" diameter wheels

posts.name: Dylan
posts.cooked:
We used 6 inch wheels.

And an update:

We removed the extra 16 pounds, but still have the occasional brown out(was better though).

We then re-added the weight (our robot is very prone to tipping over without it) and cubed our drive inputs. It helped with the browning out, but it still again happens occasionally.

posts.name: Tyler
posts.cooked:
dylan292:

The only somewhat working solution was setting a current limit in software for the drive motors at 40 amps

A 40A current limit isn’t unreasonable.  We were having a similar issue at the beginning of the season, then we implemented the following current limits to resolve the issue :

Looking at your log files, it seems that the brownouts happened during instances of 200A+ current draw through the battery, with each of the four drive motors almost drawing 80A each.  With our 8" 6WD tank drive, I had to limit us to around 120A total to prevent brownouts. image 2996×1902 373 KB

image 2996×1902 373 KB

image 2996×1902 373 KB

I’m curious what the distance is of your wire from the battery terminal, through the Anderson and main breaker, to the power distribution, then back to the battery terminal.  We had almost 8 feet of wire which we’ve now reduced to less than 3 feet, which helped a lot.  We also were using some older batteries (>20mOhm IR), and are purchasing some brand new MK batteries for competition.

As to gear ratios, we are using ~11:1 on 8" wheels as well.

accepted_answer.excerpt:
so an update. 
We did some additional troubleshooting and it all came down to the battery. 
high internal resistance and poor state of charge. 
we double checked every battery with the battery beak (more on that later) and segregated the high impedance and low impedance units.
